name: electricity production, nuclear, aluminium industry | electricity, high voltage, aluminium industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22903/documentation

This is a dataset used to create a global aluminium industry specific electricity market. The production volume represents the total amount of electricity from nuclear used globally for aluminium production (electrolysis and ingot casting). ;Electricity markets specific to the aluminium-industry are needed in an LCI database because primary aluminium production is very energy intensive, and hence the location of production plants is often determined by access to large amounts of cheap electricity, which often results in an electricity mix that is different from the general grid mix of the countries where the production plants are located. ;It is assumed that the production of electricity in general and in aluminium industry specific power plants is identical. Details on actual electricity generation with each technology can be found in the corresponding datasets.;The share of electricity produced using pressure water reactors and boiling water reactors is  is a weighted average of the share of each nuclear technology in aluminium-producing countries (weighted by nuclear power consumption for aluminium production). The share in each country is identical to the split used in ecoinvent v3.2. The share of each country in producing the global amount of nuclear power used in aluminium production was calculated regional data supplied by the International Aluminium Institute [IAI] and the European Aluminium Association [EAA], country-specific aluminium production volumes (source: EAA personal communication, IAI personnal communication) and general grid mix in the respective countries (sources: International Energy Agency or ecoinvent v3.2).;Calculations are detailed in the report 'Calculating grid mixes for the aluminium industry in ecoinvent v3', available on the ecoinvent website.

Re-labelling dataset, not representing a real transformation activity. Conceptually, the activity can be said to start with the production of electricity.

Re-labelling dataset, not representing a real transformation activity. Conceptually, the activity can be said to end with a given amount of high voltage electricity labelled as specifically used for the production of electricity.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Production volume updated with 2015 data from IAI
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: All aluminium producing countries for which there is some nuclear power used for electrolysis.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: For the split of nuclear-based electricity production to the respective technologies (pressure water reactor, boiling water reactor), relative output of different types of nuclear power plants in aluminium producing countries, when available, were used as a proxy for the split relevant for the aluminium industry, else 'Rest-of-world' split (over 99% pressure water reactor) was used, see general comments.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: IAI data used for total electricity used in the production of aluminium that is from nuclear power plants. ecoinvent data used to split nuclear-based electricity production to the respective technologies (pressure water reactor and boiling water reactor). The cited 93% representativeness is for IAI data (data based on 93% of global aluminium production). The percent representativeness of data used to split nuclear-based electricity production to different types of plants (national grid proxy) is 100%.

exchanges.description: Expressed as sum of contributing technologies (inputs) to allow uncertainty analysis: each technology share is uncertain, and in a Monte Carlo analysis will always be normalized by the sum contribution of each technology
